summary: This is an official After Action Review conducted by the Bureau of Prisons Southeast Region, analyzing the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It details a chronological timeline of events from his arrival, a prior incident on July 23, 2019, and the circumstances leading to his death, highlighting systemic failures in protocol, communication, and inmate monitoring. This document is an After Action Review from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated August 10, 2019, analyzing the circumstances surrounding an inmate suicide. It identifies systemic failures in suicide prevention protocols and staff dereliction of duty as primary factors, and provides recommendations for corrective actions.

events.title: Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is entered into the SENTRY system as arriving at MCC New York as a pre-trial inmate and is initially placed in general population.

events.title: Prior Suicide Attempt/Incident
events.description: Epstein found unresponsive in his SHU cell with an orange cloth ligature around his neck. Cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione reported the incident. An SIS investigation was inconclusive.

events.title: Cellmate Departs, Epstein Left Alone
events.description: Cellmate Efrain Reyes departs for court and does not return. Epstein meets with attorneys and is returned to his SHU cell alone in the evening, contrary to psychology recommendations for a cellmate.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At approximately 6:33 AM, Epstein is found unresponsive in his cell with a torn bedsheet around his neck. CPR and medical efforts fail, and he is pronounced dead at Beekman Hospital at 7:36 AM.

events.title: After Action Review of Inmate Suicide
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons conducted an after-action review following an inmate suicide at MCC New York. The review found a direct dereliction of duty by correctional workers in the Special Housing Unit, failure to follow suicide prevention processes, and systemic shortcomings that created an environment vulnerable to suicide.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, New York, NY
Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide via hanging in his SHU cell at MCC New York on the morning of August 10, 2019.
A prior incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a ligature, was investigated but deemed inconclusive regarding whether it was a suicide attempt, an assault, or a feigned incident.
Despite clear psychology recommendations that Epstein required a cellmate while in SHU, he was left alone in his cell on the night of August 9-10 after his cellmate, Efrain Reyes, departed for court.

The review found significant systemic failures: SHU officers failed to conduct required rounds and counts, the SENTRY database contained major inaccuracies, and there was a critical breakdown in communication regarding housing protocols.
On August 9, 2019, Epstein was provided an unmonitored social phone call by the Institution Duty Officer, a fact the review team found 'extremely concerning' but could not investigate further.
The document identifies a direct dereliction of duty by assigned correctional workers in the Special Housing Unit as the primary factor that exposed the institution to an inmate suicide event.
Failure to perform basic correctional tasks like counting and viewing inmates is cited; had these been done, the suicide might have been detected or responded to quicker.
The Institution Supplement on Suicide Prevention is noted as not required and occasionally not followed, indicating a systemic procedural failure.

Recommendations include a multi-disciplinary team assessment, reinstating Regional Psychology Administrators, reviewing staff resource allocation, and establishing procedures for video-capable cells in the SHU.
The document provides a cost/impact statement estimating over $10,000 in expenses related to the event, including medical and potential death-related costs.
